dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over a DARK SCREEN we see the caption: "This is a fairy story, an episode out of time and space, which nevertheless was real" - Colin Clark. Then, FADE UP ON: Newsreel footage of SIR LAURENCE OLIVIER AND VIVIEN LEIGH arriving back at Tilbury Docks to be greeted by an excite crowd of fans. As they progress down the gangplank and st to sign autographs we HEAR an excited commentary OVER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Returning to England are Britain's acting royalty Sir Laurence Olivier and Lady Olivier, better known as stunning Gone With The Wind star Vivien Leigh. Sir Laurence has added a new string to his bow with the announcement that he is to direct and star in a screen version of Terence Rattigan's stage play The Sleeping Prince with none other than Hollywood siren Marilyn Monroe. When the world's greatest actor romances the most famous woman alive, we can be sure that sparks will fly. Now, now Lady Olivier, don't worry - any romance is strictly for the camera!" As OLIVIER and VIVIEN smile for the photographers, we -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is 1956. Saltwood Castle, the family home of the Clark family, looms over the landscape, framed by the setting sun. It is majestic, an Englishman's dream of a home, complete with turrets and even a moat. There is a feeling of timeless beauty and stability about the scene, somethi profoundly English. We are a very long way from Hollywood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN CLARK, 23, hurries across the lawn carrying a bag, is casually dressed, boyish and handsome. He heads toward beautiful, ramshackle building and through the ancient oa doors. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN bounds up the stairs into the Library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As COLIN enters, he sees SIR KENNETH CLARK, standing in f of a painting on an easel by the Italian Baroque painter, Annibale Carracci. He has two STUDENTS with him, a man an woman in their early 20s, and is in mid-description of th painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and this is one of Carracci's earlier works and one is able to see the emergence of his now famous Baroque style, which is clearly rooted in the tradition of high renaissance and antiquity... COLIN pauses briefly and hurries towards them. Throughout scene there is a sense of his urgency and desire to go. T whole thing should be played at breakneck pace. KENNETH b affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colin! Come in. Have you met James and Anna? Two very brilliant pupils. He has the avuncular air of a benign academic, affable an little eccentric. COLIN smiles hurriedly at the students, time to waste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm leaving for London now, Pa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, yes. Well, bon chance, dear boy... He puts a friendly arm around COLIN's shoulder and starts walk him back to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can always get you a research position at the V&A when you've grown up a bit and got this film idea out of your system... COLIN's smiles but before he can reply JANE CLARK whirls the room, a ball of energy, talking nineteen to the dozen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenneth, you might have told Cook we were another two for dinner. What is everyone supposed to eat? Cabbage soup? Oh, Colin, darling, there you are... MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 2A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks wonderful in a good quality but elderly dress, eccentrically combined with gardening attire, her mind on dozen things at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm off now, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My job interview, remember..? But she is already continuing her journey. COLIN smiles hurriedly at KENNETH, who gives him an affectionate wave COLIN dashes after his mother. She leaves the Library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JANE strides across the lawn with COLIN rushing to catch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you stay for dinner? There's nothing to eat but I'm sure the conversation will be charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be late in the morning. As COLIN hurries after JANE he is nearly run down by an elderly GARDENER with a lawn mower, and has to take light evasive action. JANE doesn't notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure they won't mind. You'll be a famous film director in no time. I know your father's put in a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish he hadn't done that. I can manage on my own. She stops so abruptly he nearly slams into her. JANE look around the garden with a frown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to watch Jenkins like a hawk. One more of his murderous prunings and we'll lose the tea roses for ever. And she's off again, with COLIN still following. He can't help smiling at the madness of it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is setting, casting a golden glow over the castle COLIN and JANE emerge from the front door, COLIN pauses i the driveway and dumps his bag in the back of his old but racy MG Sports car. Only now does JANE really turn her attention fully to him for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now go and have a lovely time, darling. We're always here when you're ready to talk your future. COLIN wants to protest but before he can get the words ou JANE sees a YOUNG GARDENER walking at the side of the hou with a wheel barrow. Her face lights up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mullins! Be an angel - find Cook and ask her how many pork chops we need for tonight. Then bring the car round. I must get to the village before the shop shuts... She dashes away after the GARDENER, turning back as an afterthought to blow a kiss at COLIN as she goes. COLIN smiles, then pauses for a moment to look at the hou We can sense both his affection for it but more pressingl his need to get away. He gets in, puts the car in gear and the Bristol pulls ou the drive and across the moat. In the last rays of the su the countryside looks magical, but Colin only has eyes fo the road ahead. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 3.

dialogues.speaker: SCENES OF LONDON
dialogues.text: IN THE 1950s FROM COLIN'S POINT OF VIEW. AS HE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sharp contrast with the hazy beauty of the countryside. It is early morning in the heart of London's West End. Th streets hum with activity as OFFICE WORKERS in hats and raincoats stream from the tube stations. COLIN pushes his way through the early morning crowds in Piccadilly. This is his patch; he is very much at home here, negotiating the busy streets with ease. As he passe by the upmarket Burlington Arcade a TAILOR pauses in measuring a suit for a client to give him a familiar wave COLIN waves back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checking his watch he runs the last few yards then stops outside the imposing facade of 144 Piccadilly. A plaque outside the door announces: LAURENCE OLIVIER PRODUCTIONS. Colin fingers his carefully knotted tie to make sure everything is correctly in place, then goes to the door a rings the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The reception area is luxurious - deep pile carpets and plush sofas. VANESSA, the beautiful secretary, sits behin her imposing desk, gazing doubtfully at COLIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not in Mr. Perceval's diary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry told me to come. She pauses dubiously, then reaches for her telephone. We hear a man answer in an office down the hall, his voice carrying irritably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a Mr. Colin Clark here. He says Sir Laurence sent him. She stresses the proper name in disapproval of Colin's familiarity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God... not another one of Vivien's pretty boys. VANESSA looks at COLIN with amusement. His smile falters he feels himself coming down to earth with a bump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HUGH PERCEVAL (40s) is Laurence Olivier's production executive. He is tall and gloomy, with black-rimmed spectacles and thinning dark hair. He looks at COLIN grim as he stuffs his pipe with tobacco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A job on your Marilyn Monroe film. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh really, what as?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to work on the production side. He smiles with as much charm as he can muster. PERCEVAL isn't impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no jobs yet. We don't start shooting for eight weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I wait?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until there's a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For eight weeks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something might come up. PERCEVAL is distracted as the telephone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terry? Larry wondered how the script was coming...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN troops back to the sofa. VANESSA gives him a cool glance. COLIN looks at the clock. It has just gone 10.30. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the day pass as COLIN sits on the sofa - the clock ticking slowly on the wall, VANESSA busy at her desk, COL looking up hopefully from time to time, only to be disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is now nearly 6 o'clock. COLIN sits exactly as he was. PERCEVAL shares a look with VANESSA as he comes out of hi office. He gazes drily at Colin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no jobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come back tomorrow morning. Just in case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a free country. He sounds as though he rather regrets it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN arrives early, ready for another day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN is back in his place at 8.30 sharp the next morning PERCEVAL gives him a grim stare as he goes through to his office. VANESSA glances up from her typewriter. He meets eye optimistically but she ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clock ticks around with agonising slowness to 11.00. VANESSA finally gives Colin a pitying look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to sit there all day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd do anything to be in the film business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything? MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles cheekily. He grins back, sensing an opportunit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can start by making me a cup of tea. White, two sugars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on the clock as it ticks around monotonously to 12.30. VANESSA puts on her gloves and collects her bag. She gives COLIN a sly look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can answer the telephone while I'm at lunch, if you like. She winks. COLIN grins. The phone rings. He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laurence Olivier Productions...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Sir Laurence there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's at Notley until the end of the week. Can I take a message?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call back. No sooner has COLIN hung up than PERCEVAL appears. He stares at COLIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vanessa asked me to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, did she? Why didn't you put that call through?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There didn't seem any need to bother you. But if you want me to transfer every single one... PERCEVAL looks at him grudgingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Use your judgement. He hesitates and looks back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a number for Noel Coward. It won't be in the book, so you'll have to track him down. COLIN realises this is a test. He thinks quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings in the beautiful central hall. JANE CLARK picks up the phone. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 9.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colin, darling! How are you getting on?

dialogues.speaker: 144 PICCADILLY. RECEPTION AREA. DAY. 17
dialogues.text: COLIN glances towards Perceval's office and talks quickly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is urgent. I need Noel Coward's London number. My life depends on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How exciting. Let me see... it's Sloane 2965. Ask him if he's coming to Saltwood for the bank holiday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will. Mama, you're an angel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PERCEVAL looks up as COLIN puts the number on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was quick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a bit of luck. PERCEVAL looks at him shrewdly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I supposed to be impressed? Did Mummy and Daddy help? Don't think they can do the job for you. The only way you'll get on in this business is through bloody hard work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. COLIN leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A new morning. COLIN perches restlessly on the sofa. Despite his modest triumph he is back where he started. T seconds pass in dull silence. He is beginning to think hi campaign will fail. But then, in a heartbeat, everything changes. He looks up in surprise as the door bursts open and SIR LAURENCE OLIVIER strides in with his wife VIVIEN LEIGH on his arm. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the age of 49 SIR LAURENCE OLIVIER is at the peak of h fame. He is handsome and charismatic, and VIVIEN is scarcely less extraordinary. The Gone With The Wind star remains classically lovely, flirtatious and captivating. Individually they are charismatic enough, but together th are electrifying, seeming to charge the air around them with the power of their personalities, galvanising anyone who comes into contact with them. VANESSA leaps to her feet and PERCEVAL hurries to greet them as COLIN stands up uncertainly. OLIVIER is all amiab bluster and bonhomie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know, Hughie, it is simply impossible to get Marilyn Monroe on the telephone? The darling girl spends the entire day asleep. But great beauty has its way... He laughs, but then notices VIVIEN's less than enthusiast response. Seeking refuge in some distraction he notices COLIN hovering by the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, boy... remind me? He smiles vaguely and glances at VIVIEN for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember Colin, darling. You met him at the Clarks' party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said there might be a job on your film. OLIVIER has no recollection of this and fumbles in his pockets to cover his confusion, bringing out a packet of cigarettes and offering them to COLIN with breezy charm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a cigarette. Keep the pack. He turns quickly to PERCEVAL. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There won't be any film unless Miss Monroe gets her splendid posterior out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The House Committee are threatening to withhold Miller's passport. They say he's a communist. No Arthur, no Marilyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have a word with the American ambassador. I'm taking him to see Vivien in South Sea Bubble on Thursday... now, tell me, Hughie, are Terry's rewrites in? He puts an arm around PERCEVAL's shoulders and they disappear together into Perceval's office. VIVIEN lingers behind, smiling radiantly at COLIN who loo dumbly at the packet of cigarettes in his hand. He now se they are called "Oliviers". VIVIEN wrinkles her nose in amusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They named them after Larry. The first actor since Du Maurier to have his own brand and they pay him an absolute fortune. (Pause) I'm afraid they're rather ghastly. She cups Colin's cheeks with her hands and studies him in mock awe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't he gorgeous, Vanessa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose he's all right. VIVIEN's eyes sparkle. OLIVIER emerges from the office wi handful of script pages and VIVIEN looks at him slyly, getting her own back for his tactless over-praise of Marilyn's charms as she strokes COLIN's cheek. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's elope together and have the most glorious affair. (Arch) Oh, but then, who'd look after my poor Larry? Olivier glances over with a faint look of exasperation. VIVIEN winks at COLIN and takes her husband's arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, darling, you must do something for Colin. You absolutely promised. OLIVIER looks hunted. There is no way out. He glances bac at PERCEVAL as he comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's try to find him something to do, Hughie. COLIN grins in triumph. VIVIEN smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will take care of my precious Larrykins, won't you? She flirtatiously offers up her cheek for COLIN to kiss. COLIN's smile falters as he sees PERCEVAL looking at him grimly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN stands eagerly at PERCEVAL's desk. PERCEVAL looks a him, more than usually brusque.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur Jacobs, Miss Monroe's publicist is flying in tomorrow. He wants to see the house she'll be staying in. Find something suitable.

dialogues.speaker: ALT INT. 144 PICCADILLY. HUGH PERCEVAL'S OFFICE. DAY.
Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN knocks and walks into Perceval's office, carrying a tray with tea and a plate of biscuits. The blinds are clo and a 16mm projector is running; silent images play on a up screen in the corner of the room. Framed in the light of the projector are PERCEVAL and the film's lighting cameraman JACK CARDIFF. They take no noti of Colin. He looks up at the screen. The two men are watching make- hair and wardrobe tests for the film. MARILYN MONROE in character as Elsie Marina. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 12A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The film shows Marilyn looking sweet and pretty, chatting silently to someone just off camera, mugging playfully in costume, larking about with her hair - and then, when she wants to, turning on her full film star wattage and looki wonderful, every inch the beautiful icon. It is an intimate glimpse of her at work. Colin watches, fascinated, completely forgetting why he's there, still holding the tray - PERCEVAL (TO CARDIFF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry says he particularly likes this dress. She looks radiant. CARDIFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly - we need to tone her down a bit. PERCEVAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell do you tone down Marilyn Monroe?! COLIN laughs. He immediately regrets it. Both men turn to look at him. PERCEVAL turns off the projector and gazes a him stonily. PERCEVAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marilyn Monroe's publicist is flying in tomorrow. He wants to see the house she'll be staying in. Find something suitable. COLIN nods eagerly, anxious to get out. He is already at door when PERCEVAL barks at him again. PERCEVAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And leave the bloody tea. COLIN had forgotten the tray. He blushes furiously, puts down and hurries out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN has a map spread out on the bonnet of his Bristol sports car. He finds Pinewood Studios then draws a ring around its circumference. He taps his pencil thoughtfully as he lights a cigarette - one of the branded pack that Olivier gave him. He inhales deeply, thinking, then grimaces in distaste, quickly stubbing it out under his foot. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN pulls into the drive of Tibbs Farm, a charming English cottage. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COTES-PREEDY, the owner, clearly has a very high opinion Tibbs Farm. Aloof and snobbish, he stands by the front door, looking down his nose at COLIN. COTES-PREEDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the question. I can't have a lot of awful film people tramping through the house in dirty boots. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd pay a hundred pounds per week for 18 weeks. COTES-PREEDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife would never agree. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a pity. I'll have to tell Miss Monroe to look elsewhere, then. COTES-PREEDY double takes. COTES-PREEDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marilyn Monroe? COLIN (NODS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's making a film with Sir Laurence Olivier. The Sleeping Prince. From the play by Terence Rattigan. COTES-PREEDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw it in the West End a couple of years ago. Vivien Leigh was marvellous. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Marilyn Monroe in the film. COTES-PREEDY smiles transparently. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 14.  COTES-PREEDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (After a second) I suppose I'd have to be introduced..? CUT TO:  24 DELETED 24

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARTHUR JACOBS, Marilyn's publicist, is a close-cropped, pugnacious figure in his mid-forties. He waits impatientl outside Olivier's office, a stack of newspapers under his arm. COLIN comes hurrying up, smiling brightly. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Jacobs. I hope you had a pleasant flight. JACOBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the fucking car? CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACOBS sits in the passenger seat of Colin's Bristol spor car reading his stack of newspapers. After a moment he grunts in disgust. JACOBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez, do you Brits actually read this stuff? He winds down his window and simply throws the whole lot out into the lane. The pages billow out in a great cloud behind the speeding car, landing in the pretty hedgerows and on neat front lawns. COLIN gapes in astonishment. Welcome to Hollywood. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACOBS slouches out of the house, magnificently unimpressed. COTES-PREEDY follows him proudly with COLIN his side. JACOBS takes a long, unimpressed look at the property. JACOBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this place? A brothel? COTES-PREEDY's face falls. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 14A.  COTES-PREEDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's one of the best houses in the area. JACOBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. And I thought you Brits had taste. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances at COLIN. JACOBS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this the best you can do? COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very near Pinewood. JACOBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. We'll take it. (Pause) But ditch the wallpaper. It's given me a migraine. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACOBS slaps down a copy of the Evening Standard on the desk. The front page carries a picture of Tibbs Farm with the caption: "Exclusive - Marilyn's Luxury Home In England". He jabs a finger at it angrily. OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: News travels fast. JACOBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That house was perfect for Marilyn. PERCEVAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't use it now. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes we can. I knew Cotes-Preedy wouldn't be able to keep this quiet. They stare to him in surprise. He looks at them boldly. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you asked me to find a house for Miss Monroe I took the precaution of finding two. The other one, Parkside, is much better and the owner is very discreet. PERCEVAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But now we have two expensive houses when we only wanted one. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought someone else on the production might want it. PERCEVAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, did you? There is a dangerous moment when things could go either way. COLIN has gambled everything in a bid to impress the MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits in tense silence, staring at their puzzled expressions. But then JACOBS shrugs. JACOBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess Milton could use it. It's near the studio, near Marilyn. OLIVIER looks at COLIN, then bursts out laughing. OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we paying you, boy? He glances at COLIN with amusement. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing... OLIVIER (LAUGHING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See to it, Hughie! PERCEVAL sighs grimly. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinewood studios is the glamorous heart of the British fi industry. COLIN drives up to the gate and smiles at the SECURITY MAN. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colin Clark. Sir Laurence Olivier Productions. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. PINEWOOD STUDIOS. DAY. 30
dialogues.text: ACTORS in full costume walk past, TECHNICIANS move lights and cameras, EXTRAS are herded to their scenes by harried ASSISTANT DIRECTORS. COLIN takes it all in with wondering eyes. To him the studio is a magical place. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dressing rooms are little more than empty shells. JACOBS looks around. OLIVIER and PERCEVAL are with him, while COLIN waits attentively. PERCEVAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The set decorators will have it all sorted out in no time. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 16A.  JACOBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marilyn hates red. And blue. (Pause) And green. PERCEVAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about white? JACOBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd have to clear it with her. OLIVIER glances mischievously at Colin. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 17.  OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beige, then. Beige is rarely controversial. JACOBS considers this, unaware that Olivier is teasing hi JACOBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess that's okay. She's never said nothing about beige. Paula will need the room next door. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paula? JACOBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strasberg. Marilyn's acting coach. OLIVIER looks at him darkly. JACOBS shrugs. JACOBS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's nuts about the Method. OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanislavski and the Method are perfectly fine in the rehearsal room but they don't belong on a film set. Time is too tight. I'm sure Marilyn understands. He turns and walks away. JACOBS frowns uncertainly. JACOBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell is this Commie Stan Slavski? CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN stands in the Production Office. DAVID ORTON (30s) the First Assistant Director, a thin, fair-haired man regards him with obvious irritation. ORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why Hugh Perceval sent you here. There's nothing I can do for you. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? ORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you in the union? COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 18.  ORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you can't have a job on the film. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I get in the union? ORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By getting a job on the film. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you just said I couldn't have a job on the film unless I was in the union. ORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. It's called a closed shop. COLIN looks at him helplessly. ORTON relents a little. ORTON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose I might be able to sort something out. The Union owes me a few favours. We haven't got a third yet. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A third? ORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Third Assistant Director. (Pause) You do know what the job is? COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assisting the director? ORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, no! That's the last thing you do. Lesson One. The third's job is to do whatever the fuck I tell him. ORTON walks to the door, then looks back. ORTON (CONT'D) (SHOUTS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you waiting for? COLIN scrambles to follow him out. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As ORTON and COLIN pass the wardrobe department COLIN notices a pretty WARDROBE GIRL (LUCY) putting costumes on the racks. She has dark hair and laughing eyes and is a year or so younger than him. ORTON follows his gaze. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 18A.  ORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colin! COLIN jumps as ORTON glowers at him. ORTON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lesson Two. You don't shit on your own doorstep. Got it? MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 19.  COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it. But he sneaks a look back at LUCY as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ORTON and COLIN hurry through Pinewood. ORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you staying? COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father's place in the Albany. ORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can forget that. Lesson Three. The Third always stays nearby, not in some bloody palace in London. (Pause) Book a room at the Dog And Duck down the road. It's a bit rough but you'll get used to it. He grins, enjoying himself. ORTON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now make yourself useful. Marilyn needs a bodyguard. Sort something out. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PERCEVAL sits with COLIN and ROGER SMITH. SMITH is a dignified figure in his mid-fifties. His erect bearing speaks of a lifetime in the police. PERCEVAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you understand the sensitive nature of the job, Superintendant? ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No need for the title. I'm retired from the force. (Pause) Something about looking after a cinema actress? PERCEVAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not just any actress. Marilyn Monroe. He gets no reaction from the stolid ex-policeman. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never had much time for the pictures. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 20.  PERCEVAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent. (Pause) For the next four months you never leave her side, day or night. There will be crowds. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't bother me. PERCEVAL pauses awkwardly. PERCEVAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her behaviour is reputedly a little... erratic. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drinks? PERCEVAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amongst other things. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pills? PERCEVAL leaves a tactful pause. PERCEVAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would be useful if you could keep us informed of her... domestic situation. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to spy on her? Perceval and Roger understand each other perfectly. PERCEVAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the odd early warning if you know she's going to be late on set. That kind of thing. Smith takes this in his stride; he seems wholly immune to the glamour of the movies. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JACOBS chases after OLIVIER trying to get his attention. OLIVIER is busy studying preliminary sketches of costumes and set. JACOBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to speak to the Coca-Cola people, Larry. They're crazy to be involved with Marilyn. PERCEVAL and COLIN meet them coming the other way. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 20A.  PERCEVAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good news. The House Committee have decided Miller isn't a communist after all. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 21.  JACOBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course he is. All those pain in the ass New York intellectuals are reds. OLIVIER rolls his eyes behind JACOBS back. COLIN grins. PERCEVAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means Marilyn will be flying in next week on schedule. JACOBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll have to be met. OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally, Vivien and I will be there to greet her. But let's keep it low key, shall we? JACOBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I've got it all under control. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bedlam! The customs areas is besieged by shouting, pushin JOURNALISTS as the POLICE fight to keep control. In the middle of the chaos COLIN stands with ROGER SMITH watchin OLIVIER and VIVIEN addressing the gathered press. OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a deep happiness to me to be translating Terence Rattigan's magnificent play to the screen... A voice suddenly rings out from the back of the previousl attentive crowd. REPORTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane's landed! As one, the entire crowd turns away from Olivier and rush towards the plane. Suddenly abandoned, OLIVIER and VIVIEN look momentarily startled before VIVIEN glances at him wi a half-smile. VIVIEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems we're not top of the bill anymore, darling. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARILYN MONROE walks down the steps of a TWA jet on a rai London day. She clutches a bouquet of flowers and wears DARK GLASSES;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: her raincoat is slung loosely over her shoulders. Her new husband ARTHUR MILLER walks a step or two behind her, wearing a light summer jacket. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARILYN and MILLER walks across the tarmac towards the terminal and the crowd of PRESS waiting for them. REPORTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There she is! Marilyn! The REPORTERS surge forward. COLIN follows their collecti gaze. She looks exactly as she should. The radiant smile, platinum blonde hair, the sexy wiggle. The most famous fi star in the world, so much herself it is almost unreal. Walking through the crowd MARILYN smiles easily, whereas MILLER looks stern and a little dazed by the sudden flurr attention. Flashbulbs pop as the POLICE struggle to conta the crowd. MARILYN puts her arm around MILLER, who grins blankly. The flashbulbs burst in front of them, a solid w of dazzling light. REPORTER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marilyn! Over here, Marilyn! REPORTER 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marilyn, this way..! ARTHUR JACOBS observes the chaotic scenes with obvious relish, grinning towards ROGER and COLIN. JACOBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful. You're looking at tomorrow's front page, boys. ROGER looks at COLIN. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to get them to the hall. COLIN barges his way through the scrum behind ROGER and briefly finds himself directly in front of MARILYN. For a moment he is transfixed by her beauty and charisma but sh doesn't even see him as she follows the commanding ROGER obediently, tugging Miller along behind her, leaving Coli her wake. CUT TO:  39 DELETED 39

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARILYN sits with MILLER at her side, flanked by OLIVIER and VIVIEN. MARILYN wears a large pair of sunglasses. PHOTOGRAPHERS jam their flashbulbs into her face. ROGER hovers protectively with COLIN. OLIVIER smiles as he addresses the crowd. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 22A.  OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my genuine pleasure to introduce a woman who needs no introduction. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 23.
dialogues.text: OLIVIER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great actress on her first trip to London whom I have no doubt... REPORTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you like being married, Marilyn? MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it a lot. REPORTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this third time lucky? MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet it is. Arthur's the greatest man I ever met. OLIVIER smiles tolerantly, mildly put out at this. MARILY takes off her sunglasses and blinks. She takes MILLER's a and looks at him adoringly. He bites down savagely on his unlit pipe. REPORTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marilyn, are you planning to see the sights? MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to see the little fellow with the bow and arrow in Piccadilly Circus. There is a appreciative laughter from reporters. REPORTER 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true you want to be a classical actor now? MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be the best actress I can be. REPORTER 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a rumour you're going to be in The Brothers Karamazov on Broadway. MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm considering it. REPORTER 3 (SHOUTS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which of them will you be playing? The agenda is clear - Marilyn is the dumb blonde and shou act accordingly. But she takes it in her stride, smiling sweetly. MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be playing Grushenka. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 24.  REPORTER 3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you spell that? MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Can you? There is laughter at the reporter's expense. REPORTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So would you say you're an intellectual now? MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband is. She looks adoringly at Miller, who smiles vaguely. REPORTER 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your definition of an intellectual, Marilyn? MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you could look it up in a dictionary. This time the laughter is emphatically on MARILYN's side. One of the reporters turns to VIVIEN. REPORTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivien, you created the part of Elsie Marina on stage. Do you have any advice for Marilyn? VIVIEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sure if Miss Monroe needs any advice she'll get it from her director. I hear he's terribly good. The reporters laugh with her and OLIVIER smiles graciousl But as she smiles at him we detect just a flicker of jealous hurt in her eyes. OLIVIER intervenes quickly to continue his prepared speech of welcome. OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In The Sleeping Prince we have discovered the perfect vehicle for Miss Monroe's luminous and justly celebrated talent... He stops as a REPORTER shouts over him. JACOBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marilyn, is it true you wear nothing in bed except Chanel No
MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I'm in England let's say I sleep in nothing but Yardley's Lavender. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The press laugh in delight. On the edge of the crowd COLI watches her, amused and impressed. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A convoy of cars pass through the throng of JOURNALISTS waiting at the gate. Marilyn's "secret" hideaway is no longer much of a secret. The classical old house is elega and luxurious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the front door MARILYN, MILLER, OLIVIER and VIVIE have their picture taken by the official PHOTOGRAPHER. ROGER watches unobtrusively. VIVIEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are all your press conferences like that, darling? MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that was quieter than some. Vivien smiles at the wry joke. ARTHUR JACOBS watches the proceedings with an eagle eye. JACOBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's get a snap of the newlyweds. Smile, Arthur. It's not a firing squad. As the group breaks up, MILTON GREENE, handsome and dark- haired, now approaches OLIVIER and COLIN. MILTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is some place you found. He glances at the house. Olivier smiles generously. OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have my new assistant Colin to thank for that. (Pause, he shepherds COLIN over) This is Milton Greene. You must be very nice to him. He owns half of Marilyn Monroe Productions. MILTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty nine per cent, Larry. GREENE (34) offers them a tired smile. OLIVIER produces one of his branded packets and offers a cigarette to Milton. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 25A.  OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a cigarette. MILTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't smoke. If he notices the "Olivier" name he doesn't show it. OLIVIER looks mildly put out. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 26.  OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Milton - Marilyn and rehearsals. Let's talk. MILTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. And the studio wants a new title. OLIVIER escorts Milton away. MILLER and MARILYN are now being photographed on their ow ROGER moves over to JACOBS and murmurs discreetly in his ear. JACOBS nods and moves in to end the session. JACOBS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys at the gate are getting restless. MILLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's give them two minutes and then we're done. ROGER waves to the POLICEMEN, who open the gates. The PRE come pouring in like a mob of revolutionaries storming th Bastille. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN notices Marilyn grip Miller's hand tightly as the flashbulbs pop all around her. A moment later he is surprised to find VIVIEN at his elbow. VIVIEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marvellous, isn't she? I suppose you're quite smitten. COLIN looks at her shrewdly, sensing he is being tested. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's all right. A bit common. VIVIEN (LAUGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry fell desperately in love with her in New York. He's determined to seduce her. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she's only been married three weeks. VIVIEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Colin, I thought you were a man of the world. She gives him an arch smile and leans in intimately. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIVIEN (CONT'D) (cont'd) Of course, Larry would never leave me. (Pause) But, if anything were to happen, you would let me know, wouldn't you? COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure he loves you very much. There is a flash of sudden anger in her expression. VIVIEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, don't be such a boy! COLIN looks shaken and she touches his hand in contrition VIVIEN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least you still adore me, don't you? COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Everyone does. There is a wintry bleakness in her face for a second. VIVIEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm 43, darling. No one will love me for much longer. Not even you. He goes to protest but she stills him with a finger to hi lips, her smile quickly restored. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dog and Duck is a rundown pub in an out of the way la near the studios. It is a rough, local place utterly devo of glamour or comfort. COLIN stands outside, staring at i grimly, his bag in his hand. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 44A INT. DOG & DUCK PUB. DAY 44A A few hard-core LOCALS stand nursing their pints at the b One is idly throwing darts. The wallpaper is faded yellow with cigarette smoke, stale sandwiches curl in a display case. COLIN looks around, his heart sinking. BARRY, the landlord looks him up and down, disparagingly. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colin Clark. I booked a room. BARRY takes a dusty ledger from beneath the bar, spins it around for COLIN to sign. BARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What brings you up this way? MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 27A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN can't help looking a little pleased with himself. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here working on a film. The LOCALS look up from their pints, unimpressed. BARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What film's that? COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's called `The Sleeping Prince'. The darts player, ANDY, doesn't turn. His aim remains steady. ANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds lousy. BARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ignore, Andy - not a film fan - are you, Andy? ANDY doesn't look away from his game. ANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't be bothered. COLIN tries to impress. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marilyn Monroe's in it. I'll be working with her. BARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, will you now? The regulars grin unkindly into their pints. ANDY doesn't look away from his game, as he offers laconically: ANDY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen and Prince Philip popped in for a pint earlier. Pity, you just missed them. There are supportive snorts of derision from the LOCALS. COLIN takes it on the chin. BARRY hands him a key. BARRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room's three quid a week, first week in advance. You're in number two. COLIN takes the key and his bag, just as BARRY adds, with perfect deadpan timing: BARRY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be sharing with Grace Kelly. The LOCALS laugh into their beer. COLIN smiles gamely. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 27B.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN stands aghast. He is staying in a grim little room above the noisy saloon bar. The wallpaper is peeling, the furniture is ancient and the whole place reeks of damp. Dirty net curtains flutter in the window. He puts his bag on the bed and sits down. The mattress sags pitifully. He looks down and finds a stained and yellowing chamber pot under the bed. He slides it back with a look of revulsion CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The principal cast of The Sleeping Prince, as it was stil known at the time, assemble on the sound stage amongst th half-finished set. They chat and smoke, their scripts in their hands. OLIVIER stands in their midst, very much fir amongst equals. One chair sits conspicuously unoccupied. DAME SYBIL THORNDIKE (74), severe-looking but kindly, ver much the grand dame of the gathering, smiles cheerfully. RICHARD WATTIS leans over to her with a cheerful grin. WATTIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a wonderful adventure, Dame Sybil. SYBIL THORNDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such a lark! I long to see her. COLIN stands by the door. OLIVIER looks at his watch and shoots him a questioning glance. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN hurries along the corridor and stops outside Marilyn's dressing room. He knocks on it politely. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Monroe? The door opens sharply and a small, bohemian looking woma in her 50s stands staring at him. This is PAULA STRASBERG COLIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Laurence sends his compliments. He's ready for the READTHROUGH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances beyond PAULA to where MARILYN sits by the mirror, her reflection framed in the lights. She wears little or no make-up. PAULA looks at him sharply. PAULA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Marilyn is not ready. She's preparing. MARILYN glances up at COLIN in the mirror and smiles with unexpected simplicity. MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse the horrible face. She finds her dark glasses on the dresser and puts them o CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN leads MARILYN and PAULA to the rehearsal room. He sneaks a glance at her. She has a vulnerable, lost expression. COLIN can't help staring at her until he notices PAULA looking at him and quickly glances away. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cast are all seated around the large table as COLIN leads MARILYN and PAULA onto the stage. Marilyn keeps her dark glasses on throughout. OLIVIER rises to greet her. OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marilyn, here you are, everyone is so excited to meet you... He gestures to the company. OLIVIER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us begin. Do sit down, please... SYBIL THORNDIKE looks sweetly at MARILYN from across the table and indicates the empty one at her side. SYBIL THORNDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How lovely you are. Here, I kept a place for you. PAULA bursts forward, steering Marilyn away instead to an empty seat on the other side of the rectangle of tables. looks at RICHARD WATTIS, the actor occupying the seat nex the empty one. PAULA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to be next to Marilyn! The startled WATTIS gets up graciously and troops all the around the table to the seat next to SYBIL THORNDIKE. SYBIL THORNDIKE (TO MARILYN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, dear, we won't bite. PAULA looks at her in truculent apology. PAULA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She likes me by her side. SYBIL THORNDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a good idea! I wish we could all bring a friend. One does get so terribly nervous. It's just like the first day at school, isn't it? MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles kindly at MARILYN who smiles back tentatively behind her dark glasses. He smiles with considerable char he makes his opening speech of welcome. OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome dear Marilyn, to our little fraternity. (Pause, looks around) We may seem a little strange and quaint to you at first, but I hope that in time you may come to find your method in our madness. Pleased with his over-contrived rhetorical flourish, he gives Paula a pointed look. She glowers back, obscurely sensing that she has been insulted in some way. MARILYN also looks up in confusion at Olivier's well intentioned but clumsy joke. Oblivious to her reaction, he opens his script with a sentimental flourish. OLIVIER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. My very noble and approv'd good masters, let us now embark on our great voyage of discovery together. (Pause) With boldness and (we pray) good fortune, may we strive to create a work of art that, led by your good graces, will be cherished as long as motion pictures may be remembered. He is momentarily close to tears. WATTIS rolls his eyes discreetly, earning a grin from the actor PAUL HARDWICK. There is a rustle of pages and a few coughs, a mood of eager nervousness in the air as they all prepare for the reading. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Page 10. PAULA turns the pages of MARILYN's script for he as though helping a child to read. OLIVIER is in full flo employing a heavy Mittel European accent. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 31.

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIER, (AS REGENT)
dialogues.text: "Were you surprised to get my invitation?" MARILYN stares at him for a beat then reads haltingly.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN, (AS ELSIE)
dialogues.text: "I'll say I was surprised. I was so surprised I couldn't hardly think you meant me."

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIER, (AS REGENT)
dialogues.text: "oh but of course I meant you. I had your name most carefully marked down on my programme. In matters of this kind I assure you I am most methodical. Who did you think I meant if not you?" MARILYN drops out of character with a sweet, nervous smil MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, Mister Sir, I could listen to your accent all day. There are private grins amongst the actors. OLIVIER smile kindly. OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are amongst friends, my darling angel. Just plain Larry will suffice. (Pause) When you're ready..? Flustered, MARILYN looks at her script.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN, (AS ELSIE)
dialogues.text: "Well, Maisie Springfield...

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIER, (AS REGENT)
dialogues.text: "Oh, no, no, no not Maisie Springfield, she's quite what I would call old hat... PAULA leans across, mounting a whispered running commenta in Marilyn's ear as OLIVIER speaks. PAULA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember why you're in the embassy, Marilyn. What does the Grand Duke want from Elsie? She thought there were going to be a lot of people here and it's just her. OLIVIER waits patiently. OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your line, Marilyn. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 31A.  MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, let's see... "Oh, and am I what you'd call new hat?" MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVIER tries to continue but is yet again brought up sho by PAULA's passionate whispering. PAULA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Locate the experience, Marilyn. Look for the memory that helps you. Remember when you went to that party at Chaplin's house and you were the only guest? How did that make you feel? This time OLIVIER stares at PAULA. OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is only a readthrough, Paula. PAULA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marilyn has to begin finding the character. OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The character is on the page. PAULA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The words, maybe. Not the character. RICHARD WATTIS whispers to PAUL HARDWICK. WATTIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's half cut! DAME SYBIL THORNDIKE frowns with regal disapproval and smiles warmly at MARILYN. SYBIL THORNDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't we going to have fun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The readthrough over, OLIVIER rails quietly at MILTON whi COLIN clears up the tea cups and plates used by the actor OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't have two fucking directors! MILTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marilyn wants Paula. OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? She's got me! MILTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paula is costing us two and half thousand bucks a week. We might as well use her. (Pause) Listen Larry, accept Marilyn on her own terms and you'll be okay. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 32A.
dialogues.text: MILTON (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try to change her and she'll drive you crazy. Trust me. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVIER stalks away. COLIN takes a chance and follows him OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Christ, what have I got myself into? CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN follows LUCY the WARDROBE GIRL down a rack of clothes. He is charming, glib and persistent. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come out with me tonight. LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm working. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow night, then. LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm washing my hair. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your hair's lovely. She stops to look at him, attracted but cautious. LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I have two rules. One, never touch the talent... COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone has a lot of rules around here. LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and two, never go out with thirds. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because they're all randy little buggers who just want some fun during shooting. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not like that. She looks at him sceptically. COLIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 34.  LUCY (SIGHS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm free on Saturday. ORTON (OFF)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colin! COLIN ducks into a rack of clothes, making a face at Lucy She can't help smiling back. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First light over Pinewood Studios. Although it is August is chilly so early in the morning. COLIN stands by the ga wearing only his thin summer jacket. He blows on his hand to keep warm. A black car appears. The window winds down and DAME SYBIL THORNDIKE pops her head out. SYBIL THORNDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How kind of you to meet us. Dear me, you do look cold. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're ready for you in make-up Dame Sybil. SYBIL THORNDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How exciting! Don't you love the first day of a new production? COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Dame Sybil. I've never had one before. DAME SYBIL gazes at him with wistful sadness. SYBIL THORNDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, to be young again! She blows him a kiss and the car rolls in through the gat Almost immediately OLIVIER's chauffeur driven Bentley appears. OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marilyn here yet? COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN looks anxiously down the empty road. DAVID ORTON strides towards him angrily. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 35.  ORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck's going on? I thought you had a contact in her house. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do... ORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well bloody use him, then. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROGER greets COLIN on the doorstep with a grin. ROGER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hasn't come down yet. Neither has Miller. They're playing trains. COLIN stares at him blankly. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE. DAY.
dialogues.text: COLIN, ROGER and MILTON sit in silence, studiously avoidi each other's eyes. Somewhere upstairs bed springs creek under the pressure of enthusiastic love-making. The phone rings. MILTON nods to COLIN to pick it up. COLI is glad of the distraction. We hear ORTON's irate tones o the end of the line. ORTON (ON PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? What's happening? COLIN glances upstairs as he tries to think what to say. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's... getting into character. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dame Sybil stands alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RICHARD WATTIS, ROSAMUND GREENWOOD (MAUD) and TWO FOOTMAN in full costume, sweating under the hot lights. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVIER prowls the set smoking impatiently. COLIN is at h side with DAVID ORTON. OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's kept Dame Sybil Thorndike waiting in full costume for two hours. It's simply not fair. The door finally opens and MARILYN emerges, with PAULA on one side and MILTON on the other. In her figure-hugging shimmering white sheath of a dress she is ravishingly beautiful. Her hair is like a halo of light around her head. No one can take their eyes off her. Slowly, all wor on the set stops. MARILYN walks to the set, acutely aware of the scrutiny of the crew. She smiles nervously, then suddenly hesitates, feeling th weight of everyone's attention. Anxiety flits across her face. She whispers something to PAULA and bolts back towards he dressing room. OLIVIER stares after her in shock. OLIVIER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong? PAULA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wasn't happy with her make- up. OLIVIER loosens his collar irritably and glances at ORTON OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, Mr. Orton you wanted me to check the back projection. Please join us, Mr. Cardiff. He stalks away, followed by Cardiff and Orton. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN sees SYBIL THORNDIKE standing on set. She beams at him cheerfully. SYBIL THORNDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't she pretty though? COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to sit down, Dame Sybil? SYBIL THORNDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How kind of you, Colin. Yes, why don't we all sit down? Colin sees her chair by the camera and goes innocently to fetch it. But as he picks it up he is confronted by a ste looking crew member in overalls. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 37.  TREVOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a member of NATTKE? COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? TREVOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That chair is a prop. Props are NATTKE. If ACT members are going to do NATTKE jobs, I'm calling my men out. Every eye is suddenly on Colin. Taking his shock for stubbornness TREVOR turns to the set and bellows. TREVOR (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strike meeting! Half the crew immediately down tools. COLIN looks on in horror. SYBIL THORNDIKE frowns in reproach. SYBIL THORNDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure we're all good union members here. There's no need to fall out over something so trivial. TREVOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might be trivial to you, Dame Sybil, but it's my livelihood. He's not in the union. (Pause, to Colin) Put the chair down. COLIN stares at him, frozen. TREVOR (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put the chair down now! COLIN drops it as though it was on fire. It clatters to t stage. SYBIL THORNDIKE bears down on TREVOR majestically. SYBIL THORNDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I rather think you've made your point. Solidarity is the important thing here. When unions fall out, it's only management that benefits. TREVOR pauses, not at all sure about this, but then shrug magnanimously. TREVOR (TO COLIN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I see you doing a NATTKE job again I'll close this set down quicker than you can blink. He turns to one of his men. TREVOR (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave, Dame Sybil needs a chair. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 37A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DAVE picks up the same chair, moves it approximately six inches and places it behind SYBIL THORNDIKE, who finally down, her sunny good humour instantly restored. SYBIL THORNDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was on the picket lines in 1926, you know. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 38.
dialogues.text: SYBIL THORNDIKE (cont'd) Now that was a strike. We were all Bolsheviks then! She smiles nostalgically as ORTON appears to hustle COLIN away, muttering furiously. ORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't they teach you anything at Eton? Now fuck off and see if you can get me a bacon sandwich without starting World War III. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARILYN is at last on set and ready to shoot. SYBIL THORNDIKE, as the Queen Dowager, waits behind a door. OLIVIER is in front of the camera with MARILYN, who flutters her hands nervously in an odd calming gesture. PAULA mutters a last few words in her ear, reading her lines to her from her small brown notebook. COLIN watches intently. A bell rings and the red light go on. The camera operator, DENYS, rolls the camera. DENYS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Camera running. ORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very quiet, everyone... DENYS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speed. The CLAPPER LOADER clicks the clapperboard. CLAPPERBOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty two, take one. ORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Action!

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIER, (AS REGENT)
dialogues.text: "Now, before you meet my mother- in-law I must warn you she is a little vague and can be very deaf... on occasions." SYBIL THORNDIKE sweeps through the door right on cue, wit MAUD, her lady-in-waiting, following. She is effortlessly in command of her lines.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL THORNDIKE, (AS QUEEN DOWAGER)
dialogues.text: "My dear, such boredom! The decorations hideous, and the music... catastrophe! Our friend, the ex-King of Moravia drove me home. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL THORNDIKE, (AS QUEEN DOWAGER)
dialogues.text: (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is now called the Duke of Strelitz, he cannot of course go to the Abbey tomorrow, but he is most anxious you should invite him to the room you have taken in the Ritz for Nicky. Maud?

dialogues.speaker: ROSAMUND GREENWOOD, (AS MAUD)
dialogues.text: "Yes, Ma'am..."

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL THORNDIKE, (AS QUEEN DOWAGER)
dialogues.text: "Oh there you are my dear, I did not see you, give me a glass of that champagne I see over there. Olga Bosnia..."

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIER, (AS REGENT)
dialogues.text: "Might I present Miss Elsie Marina?"

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL THORNDIKE, (AS QUEEN DOWAGER)
dialogues.text: "Oh yes, my dear, of course I remember you well." They all look at MARILYN... and nothing happens. MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee. I forgot my line. I'm sorry. OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut. SYBIL THORNDIKE smiles cheerfully. SYBIL THORNDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so easily done, isn't it? I'm sure I went wrong somewhere there too. Shall we have another go, Larry? CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clapperboard snaps. Take Five.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL THORNDIKE, (AS QUEEN DOWAGER)
dialogues.text: "Oh yes, my dear, of course I remember you well."

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN, (AS ELSIE)
dialogues.text: (HALTING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Oh, I'm quite sure you don't, your royal..., oh, I mean, your, uh, Imperial... your uh... serene majesty." It is not clear whether Marilyn's hesitance is acted or n but the others press on gamely. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 40.

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL THORNDIKE, (AS QUEEN DOWAGER)
dialogues.text: "What does she say?"

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIER, (AS REGENT)
dialogues.text: "She says she is deeply flattered and compliments you on your wonderful memory." MARILYN jumps in, shouting her line over the top of him.

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN, (AS ELSIE)
dialogues.text: "I'm in The Coconut Girl at The Avenue." There is a pause. SYBIL THORNDIKE hesitates. SYBIL THORNDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't I have a line somewhere there, dear? OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clapperboard snaps shut again. Take twelve. ORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Action!

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL THORNDIKE, (AS QUEEN DOWAGER)
dialogues.text: "Thank you, my dear. (Pause) Sweetly pretty. She should use more mascara. When one is young one should use a lot of mascara, and when one is old one should use much more. What do you do, my dear?"

dialogues.speaker: MARILYN, (AS ELSIE)
dialogues.text: "I'm in The Coconut Girl at The Avenue".

dialogues.speaker: SYBIL THORNDIKE, (AS QUEEN DOWAGER)
dialogues.text: (TO OLIVIER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Dear?"

dialogues.speaker: OLIVIER, (AS REGENT)
dialogues.text: "She says she is an actress." MARILYN looks at him, hesitant but just about in characte OLIVIER glances at ORTON who nods. OLIVIER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut it there. ORTON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check the gate. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 41.  FOCUS PULLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (After a second) Gate's good. OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Print. There is a near-audible sigh of relief around the set. SYBIL THORNDIKE smiles. SYBIL THORNDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was perfect, Marilyn. You're Elsie to the life! MARILYN smiles awkwardly, not really believing her but SYBIL carries on with complete conviction. SYBIL THORNDIKE (cont'd) Perhaps we could practise our lines together later? You'd be doing me such a kindness. At my great age it's just so hard to make them stick! Why don't you come for tea tomorrow? In fact Sybil is word perfect every time, and everyone knows it. But it is a kind and tactful gesture. MARILYN's face lights up. MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLIVIER looks at COLIN in dismay. OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's impossible. I should have cast Vivien. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If anyone can make her great, it's you. You're a genius. OLIVIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. The world's greatest living actor, so they say. OLIVIER looks at him, wanting to be reassured. He fumbles for a cigarette with shaking fingers and COLIN hurries to light it. He smiles wryly. OLIVIER (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's hope I'm as brilliant as you think I am. (Pause) Now be a good boy and keep an eye on her. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARILYN and PAULA are heading for the dressing room. MARILYN looks tired and disconnected. COLIN is just behin them on another errand. He can't help overhearing Paula's insistent, honeyed tones as she responds to Marilyn's uncertainty. MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just can't figure this movie out. PAULA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were wonderful. You are the most gifted actress I have ever known. You were superb, Marilyn. You were divine. MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was angry with me, I could tell. PAULA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were great. You are a great, great actress. All my life I have prayed for a great actress I could help and guide. She stops abruptly and gets down on her knees in the corridor in front of Marilyn. COLIN stops awkwardly, his path blocked. PAULA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like this. I prayed to God on my knees. And he has given me you. You are that great actress, Marilyn. MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Paula, get up. PAULA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not until you admit you were great. MARILYN smiles, her mood slowly lightening. MARILYN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, okay. I guess I was. COLIN glances at her, seeing his chance to help. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really were very good, Miss Monroe. MARILYN smiles vaguely. PAULA gives him a fierce look - C moves past quickly. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mood in the Club is cosmopolitan, lively but elegant. Rows of small tables are arranged around the stage, a few young couples are dancing to a jazz trio playing an exuberant, upbeat number. The music comes to an end and the couples return to their tables, COLIN and LUCY among them. There is champagne on the table, COLIN pours them both a glass. LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure you can afford all this? COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's all right. LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must be costing a week's wages. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's worth it. LUCY can't help being charmed. LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not the average third, are you? Most of them would be happy with a swift half and a grope in the pub car park. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not living off my parents, if that's what you mean. I want to make my own way, no matter what. LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By making eyes at Vivien Leigh? COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you that? LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Word gets around. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vivien's a friend of my father's. LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So there's nothing in it? You and Vivien? He smiles mysteriously and leans in to kiss her. She avoi him coolly. LUCY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not that easy. The WAITER approaches with a bill on a silver salver and offers him a pen. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 43A.  WAITER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be signing on your father's account, sir? COLIN blushes violently. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not. I settle my own bills. The WAITER nods discreetly and leaves. LUCY looks at COLI with a teasing smile. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was always going to pay, you know. LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you were. He looks at her, but there is no hint of mockery in her s and he is grateful. LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think Marilyn is beautiful? COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not compared to you. LUCY laughs, COLIN looks hurt. LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to try so hard to be charming. You're nice enough as it is. Well, you could be. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She touches his hand and takes a drag from his cigarette he refills her glass. LUCY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Marilyn's really still in love with Joe DiMaggio? COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they say. LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She married Miller on the rebound. The papers are calling them "The Hourglass and the Egghead". COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one is which? She bursts out laughing. Her eyes sparkle and she looks captivating in the glistening lights. He goes to kiss her and this time she doesn't stop him. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colin's Bristol is drawn up in a quiet suburban road line with pleasant semi-detached houses. Lucy's house has a ne patch of front lawn, a stolid family car in the drive and net curtains in the windows. It is very little different from any of its neighbours. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN and LUCY are kissing in the small "best" parlour at front of the house. It is spotlessly neat and clean. COLIN touches Lucy's breasts and then opens the buttons o her blouse. She puts her hand on his, stopping him. MY WEEK WITH MARILYN 45.  LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a while, crocodile. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really do like you, Lucy. She looks at him shrewdly. LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. She hears heavy footsteps in the bedroom above. LUCY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my dad. She gives Colin a swift peck on the cheek as she tidies herself. A moment later the door opens and Lucy's father, ARMSTRONG comes in, wearing his dressing gown over pyjama He glances at COLIN with a suspicious smile as he looks a his daughter.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Time to be thinking about bed, darling. Early start tomorrow. LUCY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Daddy. We were just going over tomorrow's schedule. COLIN and LUCY share a small, private smile. He takes his and stands up. COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I should be off. Colin Clark. Pleased to meet you, Mr. Armstrong. He offers the surprised MR. ARMSTRONG a confident handsha COLIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a very nice house you've got.

dialogues.speaker: MR. ARMSTRONG
dialogues.text: Do you know this part of the world? COLIN (THROWN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Umm... not really. My family are more country people. Lost for words they stare at each other for another momen before MR. ARMSTRONG smiles vaguely then goes. LUCY follo him with a smile at COLIN. He grins and whispers. COLIN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next Saturday? She nods. He follows her out into the hall. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he walks down the path, COLIN pauses. He looks around the uniform semi-detached houses all around him. He is uncomfortable here, so far from the glamorous world of hi parents or Pinewood studios. He has a strong sense that h and Lucy are from very different worlds, and walks to his with an uneasy sense of relief to be getting away. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN is back on the early morning watch. A black car dra up and SYBIL THORNDIKE leans out. SYBIL THORNDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colin, dear, I thought you looked cold so I bought you this. She hands him a bright red woollen scarf. COLIN is touche COLIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Dame Sybil. SYBIL THORNDIKE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
